TI: A Literature Overview on Epilepsy and Inflammasome Activation.
AB: Epilepsy is one of the most prevalent serious brain disorders worldwide. Accumulating evidence has suggested that inflammation participates in the progression and pathogenesis of epilepsy. During inflammation, a cytosolic multimolecular complex called the "inflammasome" is activated, driving the innate immune response. This inflammatory pathway by sensing various pathogens and molecules from damaged cells and then activation of caspase-1 enzyme initiates in fl ammatory responses. Activated caspase-1 leads to the proteolytic cleavage of the pro-in fl ammatory cytokines, interleukin-1beta (IL-1beta) and interleukin-18 (IL-18), and also induction of an in fl ammatory programmed cell death termed pyroptosis. NLR family pyrin domain-containing 1 (NLRP1) and NLRP3 are the two best-characterized inflammasome members, and both basic and clinical research has reported their activation during epilepsy. This overview is intended to summarize the current literature concerning NLRP1 and NLRP3 inflammasome activation and epilepsy.
